title: Intro to Large Language Models (LLMs)
description: LLMs are deep learning models trained on large corpora to model and generate natural language. This lesson explains training vs inference, tokens, and core limitations.

title: Tokens & Tokenization
description: Tokens are the atomic units used by LLMs. Understanding tokenization helps you optimize prompts and estimate costs.

title: Prompt Engineering Basics
description: Prompt engineering is designing prompts that reliably elicit the desired behavior from an LLM. This covers system messages, examples, and structure.

title: Few-shot & Context
description: Few-shot prompting means giving examples in the prompt. This helps models follow strict output formats but uses up context window tokens.

title: Temperature & Sampling
description: Temperature controls randomness in token sampling. Lower temperature produces conservative outputs; higher temperature increases creativity.

title: System Messages & Roles
description: System messages (often the first message) tell the model its role and constraints; using them carefully yields safer and more useful responses.

title: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) Basics
description: RAG combines a retriever (vector DB) with a generator. You index documents with embeddings and retrieve relevant passages to include in prompts.

title: Embeddings & Vector DBs
description: Embeddings convert text into vectors for similarity search. Vector DBs store and search these efficiently.

title: Building Agents
description: Agents combine LLMs with tools (APIs, knowledge bases) to perform multi-step tasks. Design carefully to avoid unsafe behavior.

title: Safety & Moderation
description: Safety includes content filtering, rate-limiting, and privacy-aware storage. Build guardrails before public release.

title: Open Models & Ollama
description: Open models allow running inference locally or on your infra. Ollama and vLLM provide easy hosting for some open models.

title: Cost Management
description: Estimate tokens, cache results, and discourage wasteful runs. BYOK shifts cost to users if client-side, but server-side proxies require monitoring.

title: Evaluation & Metrics
description: Evaluation requires test sets, human labels, and automated metrics. Use human-in-the-loop for high-value tasks.

title: Prompt Templates & Reuse
description: Templates help standardize prompts across the organization and improve reproducibility.

title: Multimodal Introduction
description: Multimodal models handle text, images, and audio. Use case examples include captioning, VQA, and text+image assistants.

title: Robustness & Adversarial Testing
description: Robustness testing finds edge cases and adversarial prompts. Automated fuzzing and human review complement each other.

title: Deployment Patterns
description: Decide between serverless, containerized, or hybrid deployments depending on latency, cost, and scaling needs.

title: Privacy & Data Handling
description: Handle PII carefully: redact, minimize retention, and obtain consent before storing user content or keys.

title: Fine-tuning vs Prompting
description: Fine-tuning adapts model weights to a task; prompting tailors behavior without weight updates. Choose based on data, latency, and cost.

title: Observability & Monitoring
description: Track metrics (latency, token usage, errors), logs, and set alerts. Use dashboards (Grafana) for visibility.

title: Ethics & Responsible AI
description: Responsible AI includes fairness, transparency, and human oversight. Add documentation and model cards for transparency.
